material.mattext: I have read (or someone has read to me) the consent form and I am aware that I am being asked to participate in a research study. I have had the opportunity to ask questions and have had them answered to my satisfaction. I voluntarily agree to participate in this study.
I agree to participate in this study.
No, I do not agree to participate in this study
What is the direction of the electric field at the point in the diagram. Assume there are no other charged objects nearby, besides those shown. Select the best option.
No direction. at this point.

No direction. at this point.

Now two charged particles are shown, with equal and opposite charge. The next four questions refer to this same charge distribution, shown in 3D space with x, y, and z axes. In all questions, assume there are not other charged objects nearby, besides those shown.

What is the direction of the electric field at the point  in the diagram? Select the best option.
What is the direction of the electric field at the point  in the diagram? Select the best option.
No direction. at this location.

No direction. at this location.

No direction. at this location.

Now two charged particles are shown, each caryying equal charge. The next four questions refer to this same charge distribution, shown in 3D space with x, y, and z axes. In all questions, assume there are not other charged objects nearby, besides those shown.

What is the direction of the electric field at the point  in the diagram? Select the best option.
No direction. at this location.

No direction. at this location.
What is the direction of the electric field at the point  in the diagram? Select the best option.
No direction. in this location.
What is the direction of the electric field at the point  in the diagram? Select the best option.

There should be a file on the desktop of this computer called "Flex1251_VR_Images". When you open this file, you should see several images of electric fields around a dipole (two oppositely-charged particles). Look at the pictures and try to develop a qualitative understanding of the electric field direction at different points in space. Spend about 1-2 minutes noting details about the images, as later questions will be about these electric fields. The last image does not show the field vectors, but shows a point in space. Decide what direction you think the electric field should be at that point (don't do anything yet, just decide). When you are ready to go on, close the images file and click on "continue" below.
What was the direction of the electric field at point P in the last image you just viewed?

There will now be a break from electric field directions. The next 7 questions are unrelated to the electric field questions you've answered up to this point.

For each item, please indicate your familiarity with the question, where 1 represents "Not familiar at all" and 5 represents "Very familiar."

Do NOT attempt to solve or calculate anything!

A car is traveling in a straight line. Between times  and  (in seconds), it has velocity  (in meters/second).

How would you rank your familiarity with the following quantity?
1 = "Not at all familiar with this quantity"

item.title: VRadd_3_Volume Charge Density Area Displacement Integral

material.mattext:
A solid, charged cylinder with radius has a volume charge density  (in Coulombs/meter3) and lies along the -axis between  and  (in meters). The charge density varies only along the length of the cylinder (i.e., from left to right).

How would you rank your familiarity with the following quantity?
1 = "Not at all familiar with this quantity"

A dam with a a horizontal length (measured in meters) stands vertically on the -axis. The water behind the dam exerts a pressure  (measured in Newtons/meter2) on the dam's surface between heights  and   (measured in meters) .  

How would you rank your familiarity with the following quantity?
1 = "Not at all familiar with this quantity"

A worker pushes a cart along the -axis. Between positions  and  (measured in meters), the worker applies a force  (measured in Newtons).

How would you rank your familiarity with the following quantity?
1 = "Not at all familiar with this quantity"

A toy is suddenly pulled across the floor. Between times  and  (in seconds), the acceleration of the toy is  (in meters/second2).

How would you rank your familiarity with the following quantity?

1 = "Not at all familiar with this quantity"

5 = "Very familiar with this quantity"

An electron in a magnetic field experiences an acceleration  (in meters/second2) between times  and  (in seconds).

How would you rank your familiarity with the following quantity?

1 = "Not at all familiar with this quantity"

5 = "Very familiar with this quantity"

A wire has a linear charge density  (in Coulombs/meter) and lies along the -axis between  and  (in meters).

How would you rank your familiarity with the following quantity?
1 = "Not at all familiar with this quantity"

A particle with charge  is placed on the -axis in an electric field . The force on the charged particle is  (in Newtons) between positions  and  (in meters). 

How would you rank your familiarity with the following quantity?
1 = "Not at all familiar with this quantity"

A student is solving a physics problem with unfamiliar variables   (measured in units of A) and  (measured in units of B), which ranges from  to . The student knows that these symbols represent physical quantities with units, but the context is unknown.

How would you rank your familiarity with the following quantity?
1 = "Not at all familiar with this quantity"

We will now return to questions about the electric field.

Now two charged particles are shown, once again with opposite charges. The next four questions refer to this same charge distribution, shown in 3D space with x, y, and z axes. In all questions, assume there are not other charged objects nearby, besides those shown.

What is the direction of the electric field at the point  in the diagram? Select the best option.

Around the middle of the assessment, you were asked to view some visual aid related to electric fields. Please indicate how helpful you felt this visual aid was.
Did you find the use of the visual aid enjoyable?
Would you recommend the visual aid you had to a friend?
At this point in your life, how often do you play video games?
When you were younger, about how often did you play video games?
